metadata.case_name: Appellants v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors. (2001) 10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench held that Special Rules framed by Governor under proviso to Article 309 permitting appointment by transfer to higher category based on seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5(2) of Presidential Order under Article 371-D.

Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 under Article 371-D aimed at equitable opportunities in public employment; para 5(1) makes local cadre unit for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion, transfers; para 5(2) allows limited transfers but not promotions.

GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 made UDCs in Labour Dept and Factories/Boilers Dept eligible for recruitment by transfer to Assistant Inspector posts; challenged as violative of Presidential Order paras 3 and 5.

Full Bench of Tribunal declared impugned rules violative; view upheld by Supreme Court in V. Jagannadha Rao, overruling State of A.P. v. V. Sadanandam (1989 Supp (1) SCC 574) and Govt. of A.P. v. B. Satyanarayana Rao (2000) 4 SCC 262.

G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994 (Labour Dept), amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996, provided Senior Assistants/Senior Stenographers in Subordinate Offices of Labour Dept as feeder channel under Rule 3 of A.P. Labour Subordinate Service Rules; also made those in Head Offices eligible for appointment by transfer to Assistant Labour Officer (zonal post).
Employees approached A.P. Administrative Tribunal (OA No.6334/1997) claiming inclusion of Head Office employees offensive to Presidential Order paras 3(3) and 5(1).

Tribunal order dated 7th March, 2003 partly allowed petitions: struck down G.O.Ms to extent providing channel for Senior Assistants/Stenographers in Head Offices and Factories/Boilers Depts for Asst Labour Officer posts; prospective effect, no disturbance to actions till 7th Nov 2001; no reversion of promoted employees.
Writ Petitions No.6163 & 6068/2004 by successful Tribunal petitioners challenging prospective part; WP No.16890/2006 by aggrieved employees challenging striking down.

High Court order dated 9th March, 2007 allowed WPs 6163/6068, dismissed 16890/2006; set aside Tribunal's prospective holding, relying on decisions that only Apex Court can invoke prospective overruling.
Review petition (WPMP No.3576/2010) by appellants (promoted employees, not parties earlier) dismissed on 3rd November, 2010.
Promoted employees (appellants) held positions for nearly 10 years; subsequent promotions to Asst/Deputy Labour Commissioners; State unwilling to create supernumerary posts.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Tribunal/High Court could apply doctrine of prospective overruling to save promotions made under impugned G.O.Ms violative of Presidential Order, or only Supreme Court; whether to invoke it here to prevent reversion.
Whether G.O.M. No.14/1994 as amended by No.22/1996 violative of Presidential Order paras 3(3), 5(1) by allowing appointment by transfer to higher zonal posts from outside zone.

petitioner_arguments.text: Promoted employees (appellants) necessary parties not impleaded in Tribunal/High Court proceedings; judgment without them invalid; doctrine of prospective overruling applicable as law in flux pre-Jagannadha Rao; promotions before 7.11.2001 to be saved.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Kailash Chand Sharma v. State of Rajasthan (2002) 6 SCC 562; Managing Director, ECIL v. B. Karunakar (1993) 4 SCC 727

petitioner_arguments.text: Reversion after 10 years unjust, cascading effect on juniors; State ordered promotions without risk element.

respondent_arguments.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling invocable only by Supreme Court, not Tribunal/High Court; no justification even if available.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Golak Nath v. State of Punjab AIR 1967 SC 1643

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioners took calculated risk opting for out-of-cadre promotions.

court_reasoning.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling originates in US, first applied in India in Golak Nath; invocable only by SC under Constitution matters; moulds relief for justice via Art 142.
court_reasoning.key_observation: SC has discretion to limit retroactive operation.

court_reasoning.text: Applied in cases like India Cement, Orissa Cement, Mohd. Ramzan Khan, Ashok Kumar Gupta; not confined to overruling prior decisions.
In Kailash Chand, applied due to law in flux and non-impleadment of appointees; similar here: law flux till Jagannadha Rao (7.11.2001), promoted employees not parties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Promotions valid pre-judgment; reversion unjust after 10 years.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide if High Court could invoke; SC can under Art 142; Jagannadha Rao different GOMs, no bar.

holdings.text: Invoke doctrine of prospective overruling; striking down of GOMs No.14/1994 & 22/1996 prospective from 7.11.2001; past promotions saved, no reversion.
Impugned GOMs violative of Presidential Order as not under para 5(2), prevail under Art 371D(10).

precedents_cited.case_name: V. Jagannadha Rao v. State of A.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held transfers including promotional aspects violative of Presidential Order para 5(2); overruled Sadanandam & Satyanarayana Rao.

precedents_cited.case_name: Golak Nath v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: First invocation of prospective overruling in India; parameters laid down.

precedents_cited.case_name: India Cement Ltd. v. State of T.N.
precedents_cited.relevance: Declared levy invalid but no refund prospectively.

precedents_cited.case_name: Orissa Cement Ltd. v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between invalidity declaration and relief moulding.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Mohd. Ramzan Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Non-supply of enquiry report violative prospectively.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ashok Kumar Gupta v. State of U.P.
M/s Somaiya Organics v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Prospective overruling moulds relief for justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kailash Chand Sharma v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied prospectively due to flux and non-impleadment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Managing Director, ECIL v. B. Karunakar
State of A.P. v. V. Sadanandam
precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier upheld transfers; overruled in Jagannadha Rao.

precedents_cited.case_name: Govt. of A.P. v. B. Satyanarayana Rao

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso to 309 for rules; 371D Presidential Order prevails over 309 rules per 371D(10); 142 for complete justice/prospective overruling.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh Public Employment (Organisation of Local Cadres and Regulation of Direct Recruitment) Order, 1975
statutes_cited.relevance: Local cadre unit; limited transfers excluding promotions; violated by impugned GOMs.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; High Court judgment set aside to extent it held Tribunal could not apply prospective overruling; doctrine invoked by SC, GOMs struck down prospectively from 7.11.2001; past promotions protected, no reversion or disturbance to actions pre-that date.
outcome.relief_granted: Protection of existing promotions for appellants; no supernumerary posts needed.

key_quotes.text: "The doctrine of prospective overruling can be invoked only in matters arising under our Constitution... only by the highest court of the country, i.e., the Supreme Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Prospective overruling, despite the terminology, is only a recognition of the principle that the court moulds the reliefs claimed to meet the justice of the case - justice not in its logical but in its equitable sense."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Essence of doctrine per Somaiya Organics.

key_quotes.text: "Reversion of the petitioners to their parent cadre is therefore bound to have a cascading effect, prejudicing even those who are not parties before us."
key_quotes.speaker: court
